data.title: Remove terminal waitOnExit proposed API
data.body: This is internal for tasks-only for now.

data.title: Tab key will randomly stop inserting tabs into editor
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:1.9.1
- OS Version:Ubuntu GNOME 15.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use VSCode code editor; use the tab key to indent
2. Tab key will eventually stop inserting a tab character into the code editor pane and act as a focus switch over to the console (or other pane thats next in line)

It can take days before this happens.  Sometimes, however it can happen almost immediately.  Restarting VSCode is the only thing that helps.

data.title: Enable consumers to hook into the terminal link matcher by specifying a priority for the link matchers
data.body:
Right now link matchers are considers in the order in which they are declared, meaning any task framework link matchers that are registered will be the last considered so the local link matchers would always beat it.

/cc @dbaeumer

data.title: skipFiles stopping on file in node_modules even though excluded
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch unit tests with "all exceptions" selected
2. Watch it break in `node_modules/json3/lib/json3.js`

This is running unit tests using mocha + ts-node/register (not sure if this has anything to do with it -- seems the glob matching should really know/care about that)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/573056/23469227/0dc068d0-fe71-11e6-8469-aeda5c059059.png)

launch config:

```json
        {
            "name": "Launch Unit Tests",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/mocha/bin/_mocha",
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "args": [
                "--watch",
                "--debug",
                "test/unit/**/*.ts"
            ],
            "runtimeExecutable": null,
            "env": {
                "NODE_ENV": "mocha"
            },
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "console":"internalConsole",
            "outFiles": [
                "dist"
            ],
            "skipFiles": [
                "node_modules/**/*.js",
                "<node_internals>/**/*.js"
            ]
        }
```

data.title: command line to launch task is badly formed for integrated terminal
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce: 

1. Create a launch config using "integratedTerminal"
2. Run it

My configuration creates the following command line, which isn't valid (pehaps there should be an && there instead of the semicolon?)

`cd d:\Users\JAMIE\code\project; env NODE_ENV=mocha node --debug-brk=45564 --nolazy node_modules\mocha \bin\_mocha --watch --debug test/unit/**/*.ts`

This is the config 

```json
        {
            "name": "Launch Unit Tests",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/mocha/bin/_mocha",
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "args": [
                "--watch",
                "--debug",
                "test/unit/**/*.ts"
            ],
            "runtimeExecutable": null,
            "env": {
                "NODE_ENV": "mocha"
            },
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "console":"integratedTerminal",
            "outFiles": [
                "dist"
            ],
            "skipFiles": [
                "node_modules/**/*.js",
                "<node_internals>/**/*.js"
            ]
        }
```

data.title: Test: debug menu
data.body:
Test for #22077:

- [x] win - @chrisdias 
- [x] mac - @weinand 
- [x] linux - @aeschli 

We have added a debug menu. Verify:
* Order and grouping of menu entries make sense
* All the command in the debug menu work as expected
* Keybindings are nicely shown for commands that have keyboard shortcuts

data.title: Feature Request: TypeScript Imports Management
data.body:
I would like to see better management of imports in Typescript.  There are some extensions out there, but don't work so well.

I would like to be able to organize imports, auto-fold imports, and get auto/shortcut import of missing imports.

data.title: add --prof-startup flag
data.body: This PR add a `--prof-statup` flag which allows customers to profile the startup sequence of the main process *and* the renderer process.

data.title: Typescript intellisense not working
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Version 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version 1511

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an NPM project on a Windows shared drive
2. Use the Typescript included in Visual Studio Code

I am working on a project that sits on a shared drive.  When I start Visual Studio Code, the intellisense feature for Typescript works fine with the @Types installed.  Eventually, after using it once, it starts to fail.  It stops giving suggestions.  I have to close code and then re-open.  Either reloading the window or restarting code seems to fix the problem.

data.title: Bug when processing the afterthought of a for loop in a macro
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: windows 10 and ubuntu 16.04.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open a C file, e.g. `test.c`
2. paste the following code
```
#define problem(aa) \
    for(aa; aa; \
    add(aa))

int cc(int dd)
{
    //whatever down the macro is colored blue
}
```
As you can see, whatever down that macro is colored blue because they are incorrectly recognized as part of the macro.

3. if I replace the afterthough `add(a)` with `i += 2` or `++i`, it could be recognized normally. I think it is because of the rules you use to mark the end of a for loop.

I tried to see if I could fix it myself and send a pull request, but you'are using node.js which I'm not familiar, and the code base seems to be a little huge. It is beyond my ability, so all I can do is to report it here.

data.title: Running debugger with yarn
data.body:
I have a NodeJS project which I can start from command line with `yarn start` command. My `package.json` looks similar to this:

```
{
  "name": "projectname",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "description": "",
  "author": "My Name",
  "license": "",
  "scripts": {
    "start": "yarn dev",
    "dev": "yarn stop && pm2 start pm2-dev.yaml && webpack-dev-server --progress",
    "prod": "yarn stop && yarn build && pm2 start pm2-prod.yaml",
    "build": "rimraf dist lib && babel src -d lib --ignore test.js && cross-env NODE_ENV=production webpack -p --progress",
    "stop": "rimraf logs/* && pm2 delete all || true"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "body-parser": "~1.16.0",
    "ejs": "2.5.5",
    "express": "^4.14.1",
    "pg": "^6.1.2",
    "react": "^15.4.2",
    "redux": "^3.6.0",
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "babel-cli": "^6.22.2",
    "cross-env": "^3.1.4",
    "eslint": "^3.13.0",
    "pm2": "^2.3.0",
    "redux-mock-store": "^1.2.2",
    "rimraf": "^2.5.4",
    "webpack": "^2.2.1",
    "webpack-dev-server": "^2.2.1"
  }
}
```
I am trying to start this project in debugging mode with Visual Studio Code but with almost no luck. I have defined my launch configuration in VS Code `launch.json` file like this:

```js
{
  // Use IntelliSense to learn about possible Node.js debug attributes.
  // Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
  // For more information, visit: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=830387
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "yarn",
      "runtimeExecutable": "yarn",
      "runtimeArgs": [
        "start"
      ],
      "port": 5858,
      "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
      "timeout": 10000
    }
  ]
}
```
The problem with this configuration is that it usually times-out because `webpack-dev-server` build is longer than 10 seconds. I can increase the `timeout` in my configuration, but I have noticed that VS Code results with a message `Cannot connect to runtime process (timeout after 30000 ms).` eventually, so I assume that this is not a good solution. Also, my breakpoints are ignored with this kind of config which tells me that I am definitely doing something wrong here.

This is the first time I am trying out Visual Studio Code and I usually don't use NodeJS, but I got this project with all these scripts in `package.json` already defined so I'm trying to adopt to it and therefore all the confusion about how to run it properly.

Can Visual Studio Code run a project like this with full debugging functionality at all, and if so, how should I configure my launch script?

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.12.3

data.title: Can editors be closed by an extension?
data.body: I would really like a feature to close any editors which are not modified in git. I would be happy to implement this as an extension, but I can't find anything in the API or in any examples that show how to close an open editor. Is this even possible?

data.title: Make Terminal hyperlinks configurable
data.body:
I find it very annoying that Terminal hyperlinks just work on hover & click. Many times I click a terminal because I want to focus it; now with hyperlinks I often find myself navigating somewhere I didn't want to because I happened to hit a hyperlink inside the terminal.

I'd expect links to only work as I hold <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> or <kbd>Cmd</kbd>, just like iTerm and our editor work.

Since this may be a user preference, I suggest to create a setting for it. I also propose to have the default behaviour be the same as the editor: hyperlinks only show and work when holding the keyboard key.

data.title: False statement in warning
data.body:
Hi,

I just saw this warning in the built-in CSS linter (VSC is up to date):

```
[css] Property is ignored due to the display. With 'display: inline-block', float properties have no effect.
```

This is untrue: the only "display" value that would override a float statement is "none". Any other case is the opposite: the display property has no effect on float elements.

Heres a test: https://jsfiddle.net/wr5pgn1c/1/ 

Thanks!

data.title: Word based suggestions not working in TypeScript
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Go to an empty TypeScript file
2. Enter `fooBarBaz`
3. Enter a new line and then type `fooBa`

Expected result: word based quick suggestions should show.

Actual result: no quick suggestions. Ctrl+space shows a popup with content 'No suggestions'.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/921609/23452439/37f59c98-fe5c-11e6-8582-9591f4f2c498.png)

Try the same in a JavaScript file and it works.

I would like IntelliSense and word based suggestions for my TypeScript.
